reviews.review_text: The biggest challenge in this game is to make it playable in Windows 10! - 'Windows 10' out of 10 :P  Tips:  1. Do not use the AA (Anti Aliasing) setting from within the game settings (game launcher); turn it off completely or if you want AA in Max Payne, force it via your graphics card driver, like nVIDIA Control Panel or such - this trick fixed the crash that I always had after the first cutscene!  2. Do not play the game in a 16:9 resolution (like 1920 X 1080), play it in another resolution (like 1680 X 1050; this is a 16:10 resolution btw) - this fixed my 'fullscreen problem'!

'To make any kind of sense of it, I need to go back three years. Back to the night the pain started.'   While Max remembers what happened 3 years before we need to go back 15 years. It was in 2001 that Remedy released an action-pack video game that was the first utilising the slow-mo we got to like so much after Matrix came out. I remember it was not long after the first benchmark software, 3DMark 99 was released - one of the graphics tests included the lobby scene from the Matrix recreated spectacularly thanks to the Max Payne engine.   'He was trying to buy more sand for his hourglass. I wasn't selling any.'   That's right. Max goes after the entire underworld of New York as some junkies kill his wife and baby girl. The game is pretty linear - we go from one area to the next. Everything is pretty straightforward but while making progress the action is almost constant and it is very easy to die unless we regularly turn on the slow-mo effect. Making things slower around us allows for more precision-shooting, too. I like how Max uses painkillers to make the pain go away - not health packs but regular painkillers.   'A bomb went off, turning snow into liquid gold.'   The game aged a lot but still looks pretty cool. At the time Remedy's software was revolutionary in every which way. The accompanying music is a classic one - the game's theme was later on used in its sequels and became one of the signature elements of the franchise.    'I was in a graphic novel. Funny as hell, it was the most horrible thing I could think of.'   There are dozens of cutscenes between the various stages but these all appear in the form of comic book pages. The narrator, Max, is actually played by the guy who wrote the game's screenplay, Sam Lake. We follow Max's internal monologues - his struggle with New York's evil and at the same time with his memories; the memory of losing his loved ones, something so painful that eventually set him on this dangerous path he can never leave.   'You piece together a jigsaw and the final picture is you finishing that same puzzle, a mad green-eyed killer standing behind you. An urban legend come true.'   There you have it: a classic 3rd person shooter that still matters. A game that has all the ingredients to give birth to an excellent action flick: Italian-American mobsters from New York, amazing dialogues / monologues and all this touched by a little - if not too much - film noir.  I do not think there are many brands out there whose sequels became really good. If you like trying out classic games this is a must have for you especially since almost everybody who appreciates the modern technology graphics have - probably - already played the 3rd and last episode. You'll probably have a sound issue once the game starts up for the first time but thanks to the many guides available on Steam this can be solved immediately.  PS: Steer away from the film adaptation released in 2008. It is the epitome of how bad video game adaptations can turn out.

Compared to its time, Max Payne was a step ahead, great graphics, physics and special effects. The story line is very good and intriguing, the end chapters are full of surprises and mind♥♥♥♥ moments. From popping pain killers to cope and as a gameplay mechanic for health, due to him going lucid via bullet time to kick ♥♥♥, to plain out reliving nightmares that you must go through, this game is great. Also, instead of cinematics it's comic book panels. The entire video game is seeped with noire and is an incredible journey.  I highly recommend this game to people looking for a fun action packed game that is challenging with a good story and a character that is likeable. Save often, as it's not an easy ride.

Max Payne is 'Hard Boiled' cop, taking the role of 'The Killer' inflicting his personal vendetta against those responsible for his family's death. Forfeiting the chance for 'A Better Tomorrow' he becomes 'Hard Target' for his enemies, among rain of bullets.  .:Enter Remedy's Max Payne:.  It's hard to avoid John Woo's puns since the game's like a big tribute to his action packed movies. This drama driven, thriller TPS detective film noir tells it's story through rugged comic slides unfolding before us the game's story. Funny thing though, Remedy then didn't have enough money so instead of cut scenes they chose the much cheaper way of telling the storry trough noir comic. And in the end, it payed of and remains one of the game's trade marks. Max Payne is bitter as his name, and playing him is always fun, jumping with bullet time, spreading justice one bullet at a time. Old school is the best school, with plethora of weapons at your disposal, no 3 or 2 weapon limit, your skill is your limit as Max Payne takes you seriously, even on it's lowest difficulty the game provides challenge, and you will love it.  If you don't own this game, do it now, as it is one of the best third person shooters to ever grace our gaming community. Don't let the inital lack of sound fool you (Google the sound patch for it and it'll all be fine), this game is timeless. Having just recently started getting into video game franchises, I decided to give Max Payne a try (it was bundled with Max Payne 2 for only a few bucks!).  Boy, was it a good choice.    Due to my being accustomed to third person shooters like Uncharted, it was definitely jarring going into the game and realising there's no cover and the enemies have no propensity for self-preservation. And Max is  very  easy to kill (meaning in the gameplay, not in the storyline). This made things extremely interesting and fast paced. The AI could be dumb a lot, but I mean AI wasn't what it was now. Nevertheless, these elements made for very actiony gameplay. Although the game is set in the 90s, the atmosphere, the vehicles and the dress of some of the characters made it all seem like a proper film noir. The storyline is intricate and very entertaining and the graphic novel scenes are very well-voiced (for the most part).  And of course, I can't do this without mentioning bullet time. Springing forward or sideways in slow motion to take on your enemies is  so  satisfying. Best of all, the bullets are all rendered, even shot from your shotgun, meaning it's not just hitscan and you can see the bullets land. It's really cool.   All in all, the game is cheap and very much worth it, even after all these years.    9/10

The desciption of this game is as follows: Max Payne is a man with nothing to lose in the violent, cold urban night. A fugitive undercover cop framed for murder and now hunted by cops and the mob. Max is a man with his back against the wall, fighting a battle he cannot hope to win. Prepare for a new breed of deep action game. Prepare for pain... Max Payne. Voted to be in the top 10 happiest video game characters ever created, now in my book monotone voice acting along with a man who has lost everything quicker than he can pop some painkillers, is an impeccable decision by Remedy. This man has no reason to be happy, and anyone who disagrees just imagine having your baby daughter and wife murdered by drug fueled thugs!  Moving on to gameplay, this game revolutionised third person shooters in general. It showed us that amongst all the happiness of Banjo Kazooie or any other animal based adventure game, that there was an ignored darkness lurking in reality and Remedy made a brave move by showing us that darkness. Moving back on topic again, The introduction to the slo-mo dive shooting mechanic really turned the tables in the event of a shootout, you could carefully pick out your targets and try to dispatch of them with care as you dive through the air. Now don't get me wrong this mechanic was not perfected straight off the bat, it was actually quite clunky in some situations, but all credit for actually bothering with something new for once rather than just another generic third-person shooter.  Let us swiftly move onto story, Well let's just say that it's not the most complex idea in the book, but nonetheless that's not always a bad thing. Basically Max returns home after a night working at the NYPD only to find a group of drug fueled thugs have broke into his house and he ends up seeing his baby daughter and wife brutally murdered, so Max being Max bent on revenge swears to kill those who did this too him, leading him down a road he was never prepared for. All in all I thoroughly enjoyed meeting new characters and having them involved with the story, it made it seem like Max wasn't so alone after all.  Finally we move onto the biggest feature of the game the main man himself - MAX PAYNE. Boy oh boy 80% of the reason I love this game so much is down to this man. Let me begin by saying that whilst you are playing the game you feel as much emotion as Max feels meaning you can relate to him on a whole other level. You genuinely feel sorry for this poor son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ and this actually makes you want to unravel the mystery about the fate of his family as well.  So for christ's sake if you are unsure whether or not to get the franchise this game introduces it exceptionally well!  7/10

'They were all dead. The final gunshot was an exclamation mark to everything that had led to this point. I released my finger from the trigger. And then it was over.'  Or at least that how it all starts. This game is so noir, physicists are still trying to detect it. Killer drugs, murder and infanticide, corrupt cops, mafia and mobsters, government secrets, dirty brothels, weird mysticism and psychaedelic drug-fuelled nightmares -- it's all here. There's enough grit in this storyline to pave your driveway.  The gameplay has aged a bit, the graphics certainly aren't what they were, but the plot is sheer enjoyment enough to make it worth the play through. The only offputting thing for me was the way the villains were so tightly scripted, and the fact that they only need see you out of the corner of their eyes before swivelling around to empty their clips.

The game is rather short (but quite difficult), but that just makes it all the easier to play through it again, to see the story unfold anew.  Should this game turn out to be something for you, I can also recommend the second part, which differs in tone and themes, but is almost as good.

Games can have good story. Games can make you empathize. Max Payne and its sequel are proof of this. Remedy demonstrated a true flair for the cinematic, adapting the powerful medium of Film Noir into game form. Max is a man who had everything, and now has nothing. But there is no more dangerous a foe then one who has nothing to lose. Give such a man a gun, and he'll solve all your problems- and look really cool while doing it. Max Payne the game introduced us to the concept of Bullet Time and action gaming and cinema have benefited greatly from it. I played the Playstation 2 version of this game years ago and always enjoyed it, but found the PC version ultimately more fun to play. MP is a crowning achivement in third-person shooter gaming, but the story doesn't end here. When you're done with this game, move on to the sequel without delay.

Hello, welcome to Noir York City!  If you'd ask for 'great effects, well-applied gameplay mechanics and a rock-solid vengeance story', the answer would definitely be old and gold Max Payne. This game offers a strict line of story for you to play through. Just follow the line of blood.  This game brought us a lot of gameplay elements those still keep impressing and inspiring both game industry and gamers:  + Puts you into pre-scripted fights: Which makes you feel like you're surrounded by real-time acting AI, + You can be a Jedi with guns: The almighty Bullet Time™ + Great soundtrack, wonderful voice act, + Over exaggerated shooting physics, firing and flame effects.   The story is about a police detective who comes home from regular day job. You (as Max Payne) saw your home has broken in and hear awful things (awful, awful). You start to search for what and who's behind all of this while surviving for another day. The game offers you Bullet Time™: It slows the time while your aiming skills are preserved. With this perk, you can both dodge enemies' bullets and counterattack them for vital hits. There'll be lots of places to run into, ranges from a metro station to a skyscraper, a big night club, your subconscious (?), etc.   Here's the short critic:  Graphics: 8/10 (Especially flame effects were terrific back in the day) Sounds: 8/10  Story: Great Atmosphere: Excellent My Playtime: Approx. 10 Hours   CONCLUSION: The game makes you feel like 'a man with nothing to lose' in New York, framed and left alone. You keep shooting your way out of the snowy nights of both the city and your life. The first time I played the game, it got me with all kinds of excellence in it. My note for it: 8/10

If anyone hasn't had the pleasure of playing this game yet, well they should!  It's a really fun 3rd person shooter with tons of action and slow mo fire fights.  Backing up the great gameplay with a twisted story, easter eggs and some humurous mis-haps, this game is close to perfect.  So what might the cons be? Well, when you bullet time dodge, you can't shoot on the ground so you have to wait for Max to get back up before you can fire another shot which by then may be too late.  Another con (and this is mostly because of me) is there are no real checkpoints within a level which means unless you remember to quick-save (which I don't half the time) you'll end up back at the beginning of the level.  The last and final con is that Maxy seems to have 2 left feet and doesn't like to run in a straight line. Which wouldn't be an issue but there are a few simple platforming obstacles in the game that are more difficult than what they seem because it's pretty hard to calculate Max's jump range and his 2 left feet that seem to jump diagonally at the worst times.  Definitely do get this game because there's a lot more good than bad.

Max Payne was the originator of the film noir PC game. It combined elements of mystery intruige and shock very well. The opening scene in which Payne's wife and baby daughter are killed is more than enough to draw sympathy from gamers for him. It also acts as a fine incentive to blow the bad guys away. The quest for justice and revenge is well told and the gameplay is well defined. The slow motion system allows players to create excellent moments of killing gangsters. The death poses are well choreographed and the set pieces are excellently designed. The music is a mixture of dynamic and classical. Max can't do any of the more innovative attack moves that Max Payne 3 introduced, but leaping forwards, to the side, backwards, rolling, are still available actions to perform.  Before Max Payne, there were no games that were such effective pieces of transmedia. After, came all of them. They would not have been without Max Payne. Any action and Film Noir film fan will like this game. It is both fun to play and has a story that is very suspenseful, inventive and startling throughout.

Ultimately, this is the well-maintained and oiled Beretta - simple yet effective - compared to Max Payne 3's G11 - overly complicated kraut magic that doesn't actually work as good as it should.  This is a game that really pulls no punches in the most fair way. You and the enemies can both be utterly wiped by the slightest mistake, and it REALLY requires you to be on your toes at any moment. Nothing makes you get that rush of accomplishment like blasting one guy with dual berettas, rolling backwards, then popping back up again to take out his buddy who's trying to grenade your ♥♥♥.

From the style to the tone, the story to the gameplay, everything about Max Payne shines as bright as ever even to this day. Ah yes, Max Payne. One of the few crowning jewels coming out of a finnish game company and probably one of the most well known game franchises and one of the underrated as well, if I may say so myself. Celebrating 15 years since the release of this game I will share a bit of my thoughts about this game.  Despite being released all the way back in 2001, I think this game is still enjoyable to play til this day, sure the graphics isn't top notch from today's standards, but that's something to be expected from such an already old game. But if we do put the graphics away, it still a fairly enjoyable game. I think the story is still holding up pretty well, it keeps you wanting to play more and more til the very end. A few interesting mechanics in this game, like the mixing of visual novel into this game for an example, something you rarely get to see in a video game, not to often at least.And then there's the always enjoyable slow motion sequences, where you can throw yourself in whatever direction and slow the time down to make it easier to shoot the enemies. Then we of course got the brilliant punny way to give your health back...Paynekillers, ha, get it? Cause his name is..and he takes them to...yeah let's just move on. Instead of taking up health packs or any kind of orbs to heal himself, he eats painkillers, now if you're not too careful you will be using a lot of these, so be cautious of how many you swallow down.  If you haven't had the chance to play this game yet, or if you have never heard of this game before, I personally would definitely recommend you giving it a try.
